Award.AwardTitle: NOSS: Declarative Framework for Learning and Evaluating Probabilistic Models of Events in Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Programming a sensor network is difficult, since the programmer has to juggle low-level details of distributed computing with severe resource constraints, in the presence of noisy data and unreliable components. This project focuses on high-level specification of events and activities in sensor networks, since sensor networks are typically deployed for collaborative detection of events and activities. In particular, the project uses a declarative programming framework based on probabilistic logic for high-level specification of events in sensor networks. The probability distributions embedded in the user program are automatically learnt from training examples using standard machine learning techniques. The above approach facilitates high-level specification of sensor network applications, which is automatically translated into low-level distributed code running on individual sensor nodes. The user is thus freed from the burden of
worrying about low-level details.

The project focuses on the following three goals. The first goal is development of a query engine for efficient distributed evaluation of probabilistic deductive queries in sensor networks. The second goal is to develop techniques for efficient estimation (and distributed re-estimation) of probability distributions embedded in the given program. The third goal is to test the viability of the developed techniques by building two appropriate testbeds. The research project has a significant impact on the ease of programming various sensor network applications. The results of the project are disseminated over the internet at http://www.cs.sunysb.edu/~hgupta/TrainSense.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed several fundamental techniques that are useful
in developing and deploying sensor network applications. In
particular, the main goal of the proposal was to develop a framework
for high-level programming of sensor networks. One of the main
challenges in developing an effective framework for programming sensor
networks is to hide the tedious low-level details from the programmer
and to automatically generate optimized code that uses minimal
resources.

Thus, in the proposal, we developed techniques to (a) specify sensor
network applications at a high level, analogous to the manner in which
queries to databases are specified; (b) evaluate such programs in the
network itself in a distributed optimized manner; (c) generalize
such a framework to incorporate presence of uncertain and faulty data
and unreliable network nodes; and (d) developed efficient replication techniques to preserve data in sensor networks. We also applied our techniques to recognize human activity patterns based on sensor data collected from smart phone. These techniques advance and combine developments in the fields of wireless sensor networks, logic-based knowledge representation, and query optimization in distributed data bases.

 

This project has provided the basic framework that significantly
reduces the programming complexity involved in developing advanced
sensor network applications.  Such a framework will facilitate rapid
deployment of sensor network-based solutions, reducing the cost of
deployment and also enabling their use in unplanned emergencies and
threats.
